I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
of up to $185,000,000.00 to Gulf JP UT Company Limited (GUT) for the Ayudhaya Natural Gas 
Power Project in Thailand. 
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
A.  Project Identification and Description 
1.  Project Identification 
2.  The Thai power sector is structured under a single buyer model whereby the Electricity 
Generating  Authority  of  Thailand  (EGAT)—the  state  utility—enables  limited  private  sector 
participation in the generation sector while maintaining control over system planning, operation, 
and pricing. EGAT owns and operates the largest share of Thailand’s installed generation 
capacity  and  is  the  country’s  single  wholesale  purchaser  of  electricity  and  supplier  (as 
transmission  owner  and  operator)  to  the  country’s  two  state-owned  electricity  distribution 
authorities—the Metropolitan Electricity Authority and the Provincial Electricity Authority.   
 
3.  The  government  has  opened  access  for  the  private  sector  to  participate  in  the 
generation  business  through  specific  public–private  partnership  (PPP)  programs  for 
independent power producers (IPPs), small power producers, and very small power producers. 
The PPP programs allow private developers to construct, own, and operate power projects and 
enter into power purchase agreements (PPAs) with EGAT with terms up to 25 years. IPPs are 
large-scale private power producers with generating capacity greater than 90 megawatts (MW) 
that utilize conventional energy such as coal and natural gas as fuel. IPPs sell their generation 
to EGAT through PPAs with terms of up to 25 years.1 Thailand’s IPP program was introduced in 
the early 1990s to promote competition, enhance efficiency, lower electricity prices, and reduce 
the government’s financial burden in expanding generation to meet increasing demand.  
 
4.  In accordance with the government’s policy to promote private sector participation in the 
power  sector,  EGAT  invited  qualified  generators  in  2007  to  participate  in  the  IPP  bidding 
process. This was the second IPP bidding round since the program was initiated and the first 
since the Asian Financial Crisis.2 The early engagement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
with IPP bidders and its ability to provide long-term financing was critical, as it allowed Gulf JP 
Company Limited (Gulf JP) to extend its planning horizon, project financial leverage for a longer 
period, and bid a lower electricity tariff. Gulf JP’s competitive tariff enabled its two efficient 
combined cycle natural gas-fired power plants, with combined capacity of 3,200 MW, to contend 
with proposals of other low-cost generators that use coal as the primary source of fuel.   
                                                
1 IPPs are common PPPs for power generation. Under the IPP model, a private sector developer finances, 
constructs, operates, and maintains the power plant. Power is sold to the government offtaker. In this case, EGAT 
is the state-owned utility that owns and operates the majority of Thailand’s electricity generation as well as the 
country’s transmission network. EGAT is Thailand’s principal off-taker and performs the function of system 
operator. EGAT receives sovereign support from the Thai government. Through long term, 25-year, take-or-pay 
PPAs, demand risk and fuel-price risk are eliminated for the IPP operator, thus permitting a lower financing cost. 
This further guarantees stability to private sector participants in the power sector. 
2  In the first IPP bidding round, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) provided assistance to BLCP Power Limited. 
See ADB. 2003. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Loans and a 
Proposed Political Risk Guarantee to BLCP Power Limited. Manila. The project comprised a 1,434 MW coal-fired 
power plant located in Rayong Province, about 200 kilometers southeast of Bangkok. The plant was completed on 
1 February 2007, ahead of schedule, and generates electricity at one of the lowest costs in Thailand.

2   
5.  ADB financed the first Gulf JP 1,600 MW IPP (Nong Saeng)3 and has been closely 
involved in the financing of the remaining 1,600 MW since 2007. ADB’s continuing support is 
crucial to ensure implementation of the second 1,600 MW given current difficulty in securing 
long-term US dollar financing and the project’s sustained need for long-term private sector 
financing. The project will complete the implementation of the 3,200 MW capacity secured by 
Gulf JP in the 2007 IPP solicitation and the new capacity will arrive at a critical time. Power 
demand  continued  to  grow  in  20124  and  the  latest  forecasts  indicate  impending  supply 
constraints toward the end of the decade.5 The project’s addition of 1,600 MW of capacity will 
help Thailand maintain a reserve margin above the Ministry of Energy’s critical threshold of 
15%.  The  marked  increase  in  installed  fcapacity  offered  by  the  full  Gulf  JP  3,200  MW 
contribution promotes the stability of overall power supply and broad economic growth.  
 
CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED 
 
 
2.  The Borrower and Sponsor 
6.  GUT is a special purpose vehicle incorporated in Thailand to develop, own, and operate 
the  project. GUT  is  a subsidiary  of the  sponsor,  which  is  majority-owned  by  JP  Holdings 
Thailand, the Thai subsidiary of J-POWER. The sponsor also owns the other 1,600 MW gas-
fired IPP project selected in the 2007 IPP solicitation (Nong Saeng) that was financed by ADB. 
 
7.  J-POWER supplies electricity to 10 major electric power companies in Japan. It also 
participates  in  more  than  327  power  projects  in  64  countries  around  the  world.  It  was 
established in 1952 as a special public corporation, was fully privatized in 2004, and is listed on 
the  Tokyo  Stock  Exchange.  Table  1  summarizes  J-POWER’s  financial  and  operational 
performance in recent years. Reflecting the nature of its steady business, revenues remained 
relatively  stable  despite  the  recent  economic  crisis.  In  terms  of  overall  creditworthiness, 
J-POWER’s long-term rating remains high (para. 6).  
8.  With  over  17%  of  its  generation  capacity  overseas,  J-POWER  considers  overseas 
generation to be its next major business domain and seeks to leverage 50 years of generation 
expertise and experience to compete successfully for IPP projects abroad.6 J-POWER has a 
stake in 28 currently-operating IPP projects in the People’s Republic of China; the Philippines; 
Poland; Taipei,China; Thailand; the United States; and Viet Nam—with a total capacity of over 
14,399 MW.7 Opportunities in Asia for IPP projects are increasing as electricity demand grows 
rapidly throughout the region. J-POWER made the strategic decision to enter the Thai market 
by  partnering  with  local  companies  to  develop,  manage,  and  own  generation  assets.                  
J-POWER’s operating power projects in Thailand are listed in Table 2.8

B.  Development Impact, Outcome, and Outputs 
9.  Impact. The project will improve the reliability of Thailand’s power supply and increase 
confidence in the use of PPPs in the power sector. The successful conclusion of the IPP bidding 
round and the financial close and operation of a large-scale PPP will signal growing stability to 
the market. A major challenge for developing member countries such as Thailand is the need to 
bring  significant  new  sources  of  power  generation  online  to  maintain  economic  growth. 
Underinvestment in the power sector reduces the integrity of the system as it becomes more 
prone to power outages. Supply disruptions are costly for local businesses and discourage 
foreign direct investment. 
 
10.  Outcome. The outcome will be the provision of competitively priced and lower cost 
power generated from gas-fired technology, which emits substantially less carbon dioxide than 
coal-fired generation. The utilization of natural gas with combined cycle technology contributes 
to  long-term  sustainable  growth  through  its  higher  efficiencies.9  Compared  with  coal-fired 
generation, the only IPP alternative for domestic base-load generation in Thailand, the project 
will avoid more than 3.8 million tons of carbon dioxide emissions per annum, as well as dust and 
ash waste. Cleaner air and a lower carbon footprint provide healthier and more sustainable 
living conditions for central Thailand. Modern forms of energy must be available and affordable 
to communities, businesses, and households to reduce poverty and set development on an 
inclusive path. The project’s greater efficiency and low tariff promotes greater accessibility of 
power to the poor through lower electricity prices. 
 
                                                
9  The project’s net efficiency is 57.7%, using one of the industry’s most efficient, commercially proven technologies.

4   
11.  Output. The output will involve the successful commissioning of a large 1,600 MW IPP 
power plant. The commissioning of the plant will also mark the conclusion of the first IPP 
bidding round launched since the global financial crisis, bolstering confidence in Thailand as it 
recovers from flood-related economic slowdown and pursues economic development under 
uncertain  global  market  conditions.  The  financial  close  will  be  made  possible  through  the 
presence  of  ADB  and  the  bilateral  co-lender—  Japan  Bank  for  International  Cooperation 
(JBIC),10 which will secure the long-term financing required for infrastructure assets.11  
 
C.  Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations  
12.  Consistency with Strategy 2020. The project is consistent with ADB’s Strategy 2020 
which  emphasizes  support  for  achieving  poverty  reduction  and  inclusive  growth  through 
environmentally sustainable development and private sector development.12 Capitalizing on 
ADB’s core strength of financing infrastructure, the strategy sets forth that ADB will help expand 
the  supply  of  energy;  promote  energy  efficiency;  support  clean  energy;  and  facilitate  the 
removal of policy, institutional, regulatory, technological, and legal constraints in promoting 
efficient energy use. The strategy also aims to promote a larger role for the private sector in 
financing infrastructure by supporting PPP initiatives. 
 
13.  Consistency with Country Strategy. The project is consistent with the latest country 
partnership strategy for Thailand, 2007-2011, as well as the country operations business plan 
2012-2014,  both  of  which  target  three  core  strategic  areas—infrastructure,  environmental 
sustainability, and capital markets.13 Thailand prioritizes infrastructure development to enhance 
its  competitiveness  and  support  long-term  growth.  The  government’s  core  challenge  is  to 
ensure that public resources are used efficiently and effectively. To achieve this, PPP models 
are being promoted as a means to reduce the financial burden, promote new technology, 
ensure timely construction, and achieve operational efficiencies. Catalyzing investment in the 
power  sector  has  been  identified  as  one  of  the  key  opportunities  for  ADB  private  sector 
assistance. The new draft country partnership strategy also affirms ADB’s role in PPPs and the 
power sector.  
 
14.  Consistency with Sector Strategy and Relevant ADB Operations. The project is 
consistent  with  ADB’s  Energy  Policy,14  which  gives  emphasis  to  investments  in  energy 
efficiency, least-cost supply, private sector participation, and wider access to the poor. ADB 
supports projects that utilize efficient technologies such as combined cycle and projects that 
incorporate state-of-the-art emission control equipment. In addition, natural gas is a preferred 
source of fuel for providing base-load electricity over coal. The energy policy also supports PPP 
models that  enable the  participation  of the  private  sector to  help  achieve  efficiencies  and 
alleviate pressure on public sector funds. Passing on the efficiencies to the consumer, these 
models help diminish financial constraints, increase the affordability of electricity for the poor, 
and contribute to poverty reduction through their broader support for economic growth. 
 
15.  Previous Operations. In 2003, ADB approved financing for the BLCP Power Project 
(footnote 1), a successful conventional power plant in Thailand under the IPP program. In 2009,

IV.   POLICY COMPLIANCE 
A.  Safeguards and Social Dimensions 
17.  In compliance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009), the project is classified 
category  A  for  environment,  category  C  for  involuntary  resettlement,  and  category  C  for 
indigenous peoples. An environmental impact assessment (EIA) was prepared in accordance 
with the Safeguard Policy Statement and has identified the potential environmental and social 
impacts and risks of the project, including an assessment of cumulative air quality impacts 
covering all major projects in the air shed. The EIA for the power plant was approved on 
17 January 2012 by the Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment while the EIA for the 
natural gas supply pipeline is under review and evaluation by the ministry. The draft EIA for the 
power plant was posted on the ADB website on 4 April 2012. Under the EIA, Gulf JP is 
committed to post environmental and social staff members to implement the environmental 
management  plan.  Effective  measures  to  avoid  and  minimize,  or  otherwise  mitigate  and 
compensate  for  adverse  impacts,  are  incorporated  in  the  plan.  A  certified  environmental 
consultant will implement the environmental monitoring activities and prepare progress reports 
to be submitted to the ministry and ADB every 6 months to meet ADB compliance requirements. 
The  institutional  capacity  and  commitment  of  Gulf  JP  to  manage  project’s  social  and 
environmental impacts are deemed adequate. GUT will comply with ADB’s Social Protection 
Strategy and report regularly to ADB on compliance (including contractors) with national labor 
laws and adherence to internationally recognized core labor standards.16 Information disclosure 
and consultations with affected people were conducted in accordance with ADB requirements.17  
 
B.  Anticorruption Policy   
18.  GUT was advised of ADB’s policy of implementing best international practice relating to 
combating corruption, money laundering, and the financing of terrorism. ADB will ensure that 
the investment documentation includes appropriate provisions prohibiting corruption, money 
laundering, and the financing of terrorism, and remedies for ADB in the event of noncompliance. 
 
C.  Investment Limitations  
19.  The proposed loan is within the medium-term, country, industry, group, and single-
project exposure limits for nonsovereign investments.  
 
D.  Assurances 
20.  Consistent  with  the  Agreement  Establishing  the  Asian  Development  Bank, 18  the 
Government of Thailand will be requested to confirm that it has no objection to the proposed 
assistance to GUT. ADB will enter into suitable finance documentation, in form and substance 
satisfactory to ADB, following approval of the proposed assistance by the Board of Directors.

18 ADB. 1966. Agreement Establishing the Asian Development Bank. Manila.

7 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
21.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve the loan of up to 
$185,000,000 to Gulf JP UT Company Limited for the Ayudhaya Natural Gas Power Project in 
Thailand  from  ADB’s  ordinary  capital  resources,  with  such  terms  and  conditions  as  are 
substantially in accordance with those set forth in this report, and as may be reported to the 
Board. 
 
 
Haruhiko Kuroda 
President
